toxins.name: The plant contains cyanogenic glycosides
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Cellular Hypoxia: Upon ingestion, the glycosides undergo enzymatic hydrolysis (breakdown) in the digestive tract to release cyanide. Cyanide is a potent cellular toxin that inhibits the enzyme mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase1.
    ◦ Oxygen Blockage: By binding with ferric iron (Fe
3+
) in the cells, cyanide prevents the cells from utilizing oxygen for energy production, leading to tissue hypoxia (oxygen starvation at the cellular level) and rapid systemic failure2.
    ◦ Systemic Failure: This cellular suffocation leads to respiratory distress, bright red mucous membranes (due to trapped oxygen in the blood that cells cannot use), shock, and respiratory paralysis45.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ High Concentration Parts: The leaves and seeds (pits) contain the highest concentration of these harmful substances56.
    ◦ Rapid Onset: Toxicity is rapid; clinical signs such as difficulty breathing, tremors, and sudden collapse can appear within 10 to 60 minutes of ingestion3.
    ◦ Fatality: Because the onset is so fast and the toxin halts basic cellular respiration, death can occur quickly, often before veterinary treatment can begin3.• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual23
• The top 12 most poisonous plants for pets - Avonvale Veterinary Centre56
• Clinical Perspectives on Feline Phytotoxicology

symptoms.name: Tachypnea (rapid breathing), dyspnea (difficulty breathing), or respiratory paralysis
symptoms.notes: Because the toxin prevents cells from using oxygen, the cat may gasp for air or pant heavily. Respiratory paralysis is a specific risk associated with Cherry Laurel ingestion.Mucous Membrane Discoloration

symptoms.name: Brick red" gums and cherry-red blood
symptoms.notes: Unlike other conditions that cause pale or blue gums, cyanide poisoning causes the blood to remain fully oxygenated (because tissues cannot extract the oxygen), leading to a characteristic bright red color in the mucous membranes.Neurological Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Tremors, seizures, dilated pupils, incoordination (ataxia), and sudden collapse
symptoms.notes: As the brain is deprived of usable oxygen, the cat may exhibit severe neurological signs progressing to coma and death.Gastrointestinal Upset

symptoms.name: Hypersalivation (drooling), vomiting, and diarrhea
symptoms.notes: You may detect a bitter "almond-like" odor on the cat's breath. The plant material also causes inflammation of the mucosa (lining of the mouth and stomach).Cardiac Failure

symptoms.name: Arrhythmias (irregular heart rate), hypotension (low blood pressure), and cardiac arrest
symptoms.notes: The toxin causes a rapid decline in cardiac function, often leading to sudden death before veterinary treatment can be administered.

treatments.name: Cyanide Antidote Therapy (Hydroxycobalamin or Sodium Nitrite & Sodium Thiosulfate)
treatments.description: Veterinarians may administer hydroxycobalamin, which binds with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) that is safely excreted in urine. Alternatively, a combination of sodium nitrite (to form cyanomethemoglobin, which binds cyanide) followed by sodium thiosulfate (to convert cyanide into thiocyanate for excretion) may be used.
treatments.notes: This is the most critical step for a symptomatic cat because cyanide causes rapid respiratory and cardiac failure. In less severe cases, sodium thiosulfate alone may be used.Oxygen Therapy

treatments.name: Oxygen Supplementation
treatments.description: Providing 100% oxygen to the cat via a mask, flow-by, or oxygen cage.
treatments.notes: Because cyanide prevents cells from using oxygen (cellular hypoxia), the cat will experience respiratory distress and "air hunger" even if their blood appears well-oxygenated (often indicated by bright red gums). Supportive oxygen helps maximize availability while antidotes work.Gastrointestinal Decontamination

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis and Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: If the cat is asymptomatic (showing no signs yet) and the ingestion was recent (within 1–2 hours), the vet may induce vomiting to remove the plant material. This is followed by a dose of activated charcoal with a cathartic to bind toxins remaining in the gut.
treatments.notes: Decontamination should only be performed if the cat is neurologically stable. If the cat is already seizing or having trouble breathing, inducing vomiting is dangerous due to the risk of aspiration.Correction of Metabolic Acidosis

treatments.name: Sodium Bicarbonate Administration
treatments.description: The veterinarian will monitor venous blood gas levels. If the cat is suffering from severe metabolic acidosis (a dangerous buildup of acid in the body common with cyanide toxicity), sodium bicarbonate is administered intravenously to correct the pH balance.
treatments.notes: Severe metabolic acidosis is a common complication that must be managed to prevent systemic organ failure.
